articles.description: Gaza's border with Egypt opened for limited evacuation today, allowing for just under 500 people to flee war-torn Gaza.
articles.title: With the Rafah border crossing open, who is exiting Gaza?

articles.description: The Turkish-Palestinian Friendship Hospital has suspended operations after an Israeli blockade cut off fuel supplies.
articles.title: Gaza’s only cancer treatment hospital shuts down after running out of fuel

articles.description: Quinton de Kock's and Rassie van der Dussen's centuries help South Africa thrash New Zealand in Pune.
articles.title: South Africa beat New Zealand by 190 runs in ICC Cricket World Cup 2023

articles.description: The monarch's presence elicits mixed reactions among Kenyans even as he expresses regrets for colonial violence.
articles.title: King Charles’s visit to Kenya unearths memories of ‘unresolved injustices’

articles.description: On Dia de los Muertos, the streets of Oaxaca come alive with celebrations, as Mexico sees a spike in holiday tourism.
articles.title: Remembering lost loved ones in Oaxaca on Mexico’s Day of the Dead holiday

articles.description: Germany's attempts to silence Palestinian voices will result in nothing but more anti-Semitism, terror and suffering.
articles.title: Against the ‘Denkverbot’: If you cancel Palestine, cancel us

articles.description: Pakistan has given 1.7 million undocumented Afghans in the country until November 1 to leave voluntarily or be deported.
articles.title: Taliban urges Pakistan to grant more time for undocumented Afghans to leave

articles.description: Pyongyang and Moscow have an 'arms-for-liftoff deal', claims South Korea's spy agency.
articles.title: North Korea sends Russia artillery rounds for satellite advice: S Korea

articles.description: Israeli air strikes on a densely populated Gaza camp have provoked global criticism.
articles.title: ‘Inhumane’: World reacts to Israeli attacks on Jabalia refugee camp

articles.description:
ROME, Nov 03 (IPS) - On October 28, Armita Geravand, a 16-year-old Iranian teenager, passed away a month after she had been beaten by the police in the Tehran subway for not wearing the Islamic veil correctly.

Read the full story, “Iran, a Murdered Teenager and a Fading Protest”, on globalissues.org →
articles.title: Iran, a Murdered Teenager and a Fading Protest

articles.description:
MONTEVIDEO, Uruguay, Nov 03 (IPS) - For many of Argentina’s voters the choice in the 19 November presidential runoff is between the lesser of two evils: Sergio Massa, economy minister of a government that’s presiding over a once-in-a-generation economic meltdown with a whopping 140-per cent inflation rate, or Javier Milei, a far-right libertarian who admires Donald Trump, wants to shut down the Central Bank and wields a chainsaw in public as a symbol of his willingness to slash the state. Many will rue that it ever came to this.

Read the full story, “Argentina: Unpalatable Choices in Election Plagued with Uncertainty”, on globalissues.org →
articles.title: Argentina: Unpalatable Choices in Election Plagued with Uncertainty

articles.description:
SAINT LUCIA, Nov 03 (IPS) - Amid fears that global shocks like the COVID-19 pandemic have eroded progress toward gender equality, the Commonwealth Foundation has created an online platform that takes civil society’s recommendations for the empowerment of women and girls directly to policymakers.On August 22, 2023, Women's Affairs Ministers from the Commonwealth huddled in a room at the Atlantis Resort in the Bahamas. For the first time since the COVID-19 pandemic, they were meeting in person.

Read the full story, “Commonwealth Civil Society Offers Ministers Crucial Recommendations for Gender Equality Advancement”, on globalissues.org →
articles.title: Commonwealth Civil Society Offers Ministers Crucial Recommendations for Gender Equality Advancement

articles.description:
COLOMBO, Sri Lanka, Nov 03 (IPS) - During her 2013 visit to Sri Lanka, then UN Human Rights Commissioner Navi Pillay wanted to lay a wreath to commemorate the war-dead. "When I go to a country, I like to honour the victims, all victims, victims of LTTE, soldiers, families,” she explained.

Read the full story, “Gaza Spells Jungle”, on globalissues.org →
articles.title: Gaza Spells Jungle

articles.description:
FREETOWN, Nov 03 (IPS) - Thirty-three years ago, Bala Amerasekaran – a Sri Lankan by birth – visited Freetown, Sierra Leone. Since then, the West African nation has been his home, where Amerasekaran has dedicated his life to conserving the chimpanzee – Sierra Leone’s national animal.

Read the full story, “Deforestation, Encroachment Threaten West Africa's One Health Plans”, on globalissues.org →
articles.title: Deforestation, Encroachment Threaten West Africa's One Health Plans

articles.description:
Myanmar witnessed a sharp escalation in fighting between the military and opposition groups this week fuelling a surge in new displacements, the UN humanitarian wing has said.

Read the full story, “Sharp uptick in fighting in Myanmar, UN humanitarians report”, on globalissues.org →
articles.title: Sharp uptick in fighting in Myanmar, UN humanitarians report

articles.description:
Russia has bombarded more than 100 Ukrainian towns across nearly half of its regions in the past two days according to the Ukrainian Government, many near the frontlines.

Read the full story, “Ukraine: UN condemns latest wave of Russian attacks”, on globalissues.org →
articles.title: Ukraine: UN condemns latest wave of Russian attacks

articles.description:
Spanning from city to savannah, and from mountaintops to mangroves, the world’s 748 biosphere reserves are being celebrated this Friday for their diversity and contribution to a green global future.

Read the full story, “World’s diverse biospheres ‘making peace with the natural world’”, on globalissues.org →
articles.title: World’s diverse biospheres ‘making peace with the natural world’

articles.description:
The UN human rights office (OHCHR) expressed alarm on Friday over reports that in Sudan, women and girls are being abducted, chained and held in “inhuman, degrading slave-like conditions” in areas controlled by the Rapid Support Forces (RSF) in Darfur.

Read the full story, “Sudan: Women and girls abducted, held ‘in slave-like conditions’ in Darfur”, on globalissues.org →
articles.title: Sudan: Women and girls abducted, held ‘in slave-like conditions’ in Darfur

articles.description:
UN agencies on Friday called on Pakistan to continue protecting children and families seeking safety amidst rising concerns over the Government’s new ‘Illegal Foreigners Repatriation Plan’.

Read the full story, “World News in Brief: Protection call for refugees in Pakistan, ‘One Health’ plan launched, radio waves saving lives”, on globalissues.org →
articles.title: World News in Brief: Protection call for refugees in Pakistan, ‘One Health’ plan launched, radio waves saving lives

articles.description:
SHOPIAN, INDIA, Nov 02 (IPS) - Of Kashmir’s seven million inhabitants, a staggering one million rely directly on apple farming. The region is pivotal in India’s apple and horticulture production, contributing to over 70 percent of the country’s apple supply. This not only provides income to farmers but also sustains a vast network of laborers, traders, and transporters within the fruit economy.

Read the full story, “Kashmir's Apple Industry Faces Dire Threats as Climate Change Takes its Toll”, on globalissues.org →
articles.title: Kashmir's Apple Industry Faces Dire Threats as Climate Change Takes its Toll

articles.description:
ACAPULCO, Mexico, Nov 02 (IPS) - Acapulco is a paradise. A port of golden sunsets, toasted sand, and deep blue sea. Its dream beaches captivated the hearts of Elvis Presley and Elizabeth Taylor. US President John F. Kennedy chose its shores to spend his honeymoon with Jackie Kennedy. Its luxury hotels and the untamed sea made it the most famous tourist destination in Mexico.

Read the full story, “Hurricane Otis and the Indifference Toward the Children of Acapulco”, on globalissues.org →
articles.title: Hurricane Otis and the Indifference Toward the Children of Acapulco

articles.description:
KATHMANDU, Nepal, Nov 02 (IPS) - Many observers found it intriguing that UN Secretary-General António Guterres would want to spend three full days in Nepal even as Israel was carpet-bombing Gaza.

Read the full story, “António Guterres in Nepal: Transitional Justice to the Fore”, on globalissues.org →
articles.title: António Guterres in Nepal: Transitional Justice to the Fore

articles.description:
The UN Secretary-General on Thursday stressed that global oversight of emerging artificial intelligence (AI) technology should be based on the UN Charter’s core principles and ensure full respect for human rights.

Read the full story, “At UK’s AI Summit, Guterres says risks outweigh rewards without global oversight”, on globalissues.org →
articles.title: At UK’s AI Summit, Guterres says risks outweigh rewards without global oversight

articles.description:
Russia on Thursday announced it was revoking its ratification of the UN-backed Comprehensive Nuclear Test Bank Treaty (CTBT), after the Russian Duma passed legislation last month.

Read the full story, “World News in Brief: Russia pulls out of nuclear test ban treaty, climate ‘health crisis’, pushback against bullying”, on globalissues.org →
articles.title: World News in Brief: Russia pulls out of nuclear test ban treaty, climate ‘health crisis’, pushback against bullying

articles.description:
Iran must end policies and practices “which amount to total impunity for acts of gender persecution against women and girls”, a group of experts appointed by the UN Human Rights Council said on Thursday.

Read the full story, “Iran urged to end new rights clampdown following teenage girl’s death”, on globalissues.org →
articles.title: Iran urged to end new rights clampdown following teenage girl’s death

articles.description:
New data from the UN Educational, Scientific and Cultural Organization (UNESCO) has revealed a worrying rise in violence against journalists during election periods, and usually at the hands of law enforcement agents.

Read the full story, “Day highlighting journalists under fire focuses on protection during elections”, on globalissues.org →
articles.title: Day highlighting journalists under fire focuses on protection during elections

articles.description:
The UN General Assembly is expected to vote on its annual resolution later on Thursday in New York which calls on the United States to end its economic and trade embargo against Cuba, first imposed in 1960. Follow our live coverage as the vote on the resolution nears...

Read the full story, “UPDATING LIVE: UN General Assembly debates US embargo against Cuba”, on globalissues.org →
articles.title: UPDATING LIVE: UN General Assembly debates US embargo against Cuba

articles.description:
The number of people killed in Gaza is nearing the 9,000 mark amid mounting concerns over the aftermath of Israeli airstrikes on a densely-populated refugee camp near Gaza City, while a key hospital has stopped operations and UN humanitarians are unable to deliver aid to the north as the ground war intensifies.

Read the full story, “Israel-Palestine crisis: Gaza’s north cut off from aid; death toll rising”, on globalissues.org →
articles.title: Israel-Palestine crisis: Gaza’s north cut off from aid; death toll rising

articles.description:
Instead of accelerating to meet the challenge of rising emissions, progress on climate adaptation is slowing across the board, a new report published on Thursday by the UN’s environment agency finds.

Read the full story, “Climate action: ‘Take steps to close the adaptation gap, now’”, on globalissues.org →
articles.title: Climate action: ‘Take steps to close the adaptation gap, now’

articles.description:
CHIPATA, ZAMBIA, Nov 01 (IPS) - As we approach the forest in the village to appreciate Andrew Mbewe’s beekeeping enterprise, a bee from a hive close to the edge of the natural woodland stings him on the cheek.

Read the full story, “Communities Taking a Sting Out of Poaching With Alternative Livelihoods”, on globalissues.org →
articles.title: Communities Taking a Sting Out of Poaching With Alternative Livelihoods

articles.description:
UNITED NATIONS, Nov 01 (IPS) - In an address to the UN Security CouncilThank you for your presence here with us in New York, and for the special dedication that Brazil has given to peace in our region.

I also pay special tribute to our briefers, and to their teams’ dedicated work in the most unimaginable circumstances on the ground in the Gaza Strip.

Read the full story, “The Killings in Gaza Should Stain Our Moral Conscience”, on globalissues.org →
articles.title: The Killings in Gaza Should Stain Our Moral Conscience

articles.description:
KUALA LUMPUR, Malaysia, Nov 01 (IPS) - Governments the world over are worried about investor-state dispute settlement (ISDS) rules. These allow foreign investors to sue them for billions over new laws or policies reducing their profits.

Read the full story, “Even Rich Nations Now Worried About Investor-State Dispute Settlements”, on globalissues.org →
articles.title: Even Rich Nations Now Worried About Investor-State Dispute Settlements

articles.author: Suzanne Kelly
articles.description:
EXPERT PERSPECTIVE / OPINION — When Russian President Vladimir Putin rose to power in the late 1990’s and early 2000’s, one of his promises to [...] More 
The post The Price of Putin’s Unkept Promises appeared first on The Cipher Brief.
articles.title: The Price of Putin’s Unkept Promises

sources.title: World News Headlines, Latest International News, World Breaking News - Times of India

articles.description: Japan came in last in a global ranking of employees' well being, measured by assessing physical, mental, social and spiritual health, the results of a survey conducted by McKinsey health institute showed. The island nation scored 25% in the poll of more than 30,000 workers across 30 countries, according to the study. Turkiye was highest at 78%, followed by 76% for India and 75% for China. The global average was 57%. According to the survey, employees who had positive work experiences reported better holistic health, are more innovative at work and show higher job performance.
articles.title: In global employee well-being survey, India second after Turkiye; Japan last

articles.description: Sam Bankman-Fried, the founder of FTX cryptocurrency exchange, has been convicted of fraud by a New York jury. The jury found him guilty of stealing at least $10 billion from customers and investors. Bankman-Fried, once worth over $20 billion, is now facing a maximum sentence of 110 years. The conviction is a significant victory for US attorney Damian Williams, who described Bankman-Fried's actions as "one of the biggest financial frauds in US history." Bankman-Fried is expected to appeal the verdict.
articles.title: FTX crypto mogul convicted of fraud, faces max of 110 yrs in jail

articles.description: The US has been flying surveillance drones over Gaza in search of hostages taken by Hamas when the Palestinian militant group attacked Israel on Oct. 7, two US officials said. The officials said the US was flying intelligence gathering drones over Gaza to assist with hostage location efforts. One of the officials said they had been carrying out the drone flights for over a week. US officials said 10 Americans who remain unaccounted for may be among the more than 200 taken as hostages into Gaza, where they are believed to be held in Hamas' extensive tunnel network.
articles.title: US drones fly over Gaza in search for American hostages

articles.description: Hezbollah leader Hassan Nasrallah said Friday that his powerful militia is already engaged in unprecedented cross-border fighting with Israel along the Lebanon-Israel border and threatened a further escalation. In the televised remarks - Nasrallah's first since the beginning of the Hamas-Israel war - he stopped short of announcing that his Lebanese militia would fully enter the war, a move that would have devastating consequences for both Lebanon and Israel.
articles.title: Hezbollah chief threatens escalation

articles.author: Omer Farooq Khan
articles.description: Afghanistan slammed Pakistan for the treatment meted out to its nationals, saying the decision to expel refugees was "unilateral" as it was taken by Islamabad without consulting Kabul. In an audio clip shared on social media, Afghanistan's interim defence minister, Mullah Muhammad Yaqub Mujahid, criticised Pakistan's caretaker government, headed by a military-sponsored PM of Pashtun-origin, Anwaarul Haq Kakar, for failing to consider the consequences of its action expelling refugees.
articles.title: Afghanistan slams Pakistan, says expelling refugees move 'unilateral'

articles.description: The Kremlin on Friday dismissed a Wall Street Journal report that United States intelligence believed Russia's Wagner mercenary group plans to provide Hezbollah with an air defence system, saying such talk was unfounded. "We have already said that, de-facto, such a group (Wagner) does not exist," Kremlin spokesman Dmitry Peskov said. "All of these musings are as a rule based on nothing and have no foundation," Peskov said when asked about the report.
articles.title: Wagner to give Hezbollah air defence system? Kremlin dismisses report

articles.description: US Secretary of State Antony Blinken has called on Israel to temporarily halt its military offensive in Gaza to allow for aid to enter the Palestinian enclave. However, Israeli Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu has rejected the idea unless the Hamas militants release the 240 hostages they are holding. Blinken has emphasized the need for Israel to protect Palestinian civilians in Gaza. The US has dismissed international calls for a ceasefire but has sought to persuade Israel to accept localized pauses.
articles.title: Bibi rules out Gaza ceasefire as Blinken seeks civilian protection

articles.description: Meta Platforms Inc. Chief Executive Officer Mark Zuckerberg underwent surgery to repair a torn knee ligament sustained during a mixed martial arts session, he said Friday in a post on Instagram. “Tore my ACL sparring and just got out of surgery to replace it,” Zuckerberg wrote in the caption of a post with a series of photos showing him in a hospital bed, his knee bandaged and in a brace. The CEO, 39, said he plans to continuing his training for “a competitive MMA fight early next year.”
articles.title: Mark Zuckerberg undergoes surgery for martial arts knee injury

articles.description: The Army reservist who carried out the shootings in a bowling alley and a bar in Lewiston, Maine, was alive and potentially on the run for more than 24 hours after the incident, according to the state's medical examiner. Robert Card died from a self-inflicted gunshot, which likely occurred eight to 12 hours before his body was found in a tractor-trailer. Concerns about Card's mental state had been raised prior to the shootings, and law enforcement agencies came under scrutiny for not finding his body sooner.
articles.title: Maine mass shooter was alive for most of massive 2-day search, autopsy suggests

articles.description: A Chinese art gallery, The Paintings Say Arirang, is openly selling North Korean art in Beijing, despite UN sanctions prohibiting such sales. The gallery, which operates a studio for North Korean artists, showcases the unique socialist realist style of North Korean art that appeals to a niche audience. China's lax enforcement of the sanctions targeting North Korea's nuclear program allows for the continued sale of North Korean art. The art is seen as a form of propaganda, with artists working directly for North Korea's authorities to create art glorifying the state and its ideology.
articles.title: North Korean art sells in China despite UN sanctions over nuclear programme

articles.description: Israeli Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu has rejected US calls for a humanitarian pause in the Israel-Hamas war, stating that they will continue unless the hostages held by Hamas are released. Hezbollah leader Hassan Nasrallah has also stated that his group is undeterred by US warnings to stay out of the war. Israeli troops have closed in on Gaza City, launching targeted attacks on militant cells. The death toll in the conflict continues to rise, with over 9,000 Palestinians and 1,400 Israelis killed.
articles.title: Israel rebuffs US push for humanitarian pause, says hostages must be released first

articles.description: A recent solar storm caused a unique combination of red and green lights in the night sky above Canada, creating a strange image of orange pillars. Experts say that orange auroras shouldn't exist as the color is usually overwhelmed by other colors given off by excited molecules. The phenomenon was captured in a photograph by aurora photographer Harlan Thomas, who described the orange hue as "sublime." The last time such vibrant orange auroras were seen was during the Halloween storm of 2003.
articles.title: Solar storm causes pumpkin-colored auroras to fill sky

articles.description: Ukrainian shelling in the Russian-occupied southern Kherson region resulted in the death of nine individuals, according to Moscow-installed occupational authorities. The attack occurred as Kyiv conducts a counteroffensive to regain territory from Russian forces in southern Ukraine. "Nine dead people were pulled out from under the rubble," Vladimir Saldo, the Russian-installed head of the Moscow-occupied Kherson region, told Russian state television.
articles.title: Ukraine shelling kills 9 in occupied south: local official

articles.description: Israeli President Isaac Herzog met with the ambassadors of Thailand, the Philippines, Tanzania, and Nepal to discuss the terror invasion carried out by Hamas in southwestern Israel. The ambassadors expressed concern for their citizens who were killed, injured, or taken hostage during the attack. President Herzog emphasized that Hamas does not differentiate between religions or countries and assured the ambassadors that the Israeli people appreciate their citizens. Among foreign countries, Thailand had the second-highest number of fatalities and a significant number of citizens taken hostage by Hamas. The Thai ambassador expressed concern for the well-being of the Thai people in Israel and asked for assistance in locating and helping the abducted individuals.
articles.title: Israeli President meets with envoys whose citizens were murdered and abducted by Hamas

articles.description: Hezbollah leader Hassan Nasrallah has stated that his militia is currently engaged in cross-border fighting with Israel along the Lebanon-Israel border and threatened further escalation. Nasrallah stopped short of announcing that his Lebanese militia would fully enter the war, but warned that Hezbollah is prepared for all options.  Nasrallah's speech has been widely anticipated as an indication of whether the Israel-Hamas conflict could escalate into a regional war.
articles.title: Lebanon's militant Hezbollah leader threatens escalation with Israel as its war with Hamas rages on

articles.description: Record-breaking rain produced floods in a vast swath of Italy's Tuscany region as Storm Ciaran pushed into the country overnight trapping residents in their homes, inundating hospitals and overturning cars. At least five people were killed, bringing the storm's death toll in western Europe to 12 on Friday. Italian Civil Protection authorities said 200 millimeters (nearly 8 inches) of rain fell in a three-hour period, from the coastal city of Livorno to the inland valley of Mugello, and caused riverbanks to overflow. Video shows at least a dozen cars getting pushed down a flooded road.
articles.title: Storm Ciaran kills 5, taking European death toll to 12

articles.description: US Secretary of State Antony Blinken has urged Israeli leaders to implement humanitarian pauses in their conflict with Hamas in Gaza. The purpose of these pauses would be to allow for the delivery of aid to the Palestinian enclave and facilitate the release of hostages. Blinken discussed the details of these pauses with Israeli Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu and the war cabinet, emphasizing the need to ensure that Hamas does not exploit the pauses for its own advantage.
articles.title: Anthony Blinken in Israel urges humanitarian pauses in Gaza war

articles.description: An Iranian court has sentenced a female gym trainer to death for adultery. The woman's husband reported her to the police after finding her with another man at their home, whom he discovered through surveillance cameras. Although Iranian law allows for appeals, the country has faced international criticism for its frequent use of the death penalty. The United Nations Secretary-General, Antonio Guterres, warned that Iran was executing people at an "alarming rate." Crimes such as adultery, sodomy, murder, rape, armed robbery, kidnapping, and drug trafficking are all punishable by death in Iran.
articles.title: Iran sentences a woman to death for adultery

articles.description: Canadian defence minister Bill Blair informed the press on Friday that a Chinese military aircraft discharged flares toward a Canadian helicopter in international waters the previous Sunday. He stated that Ottawa intends to communicate its concerns to Beijing. This marks the second instance within a two-week period where Canada has raised accusations of unsafe conduct by China's air force. In mid-October, Minister Blair reported that a Chinese fighter jet had approached within five meters (approximately 16 feet) of a surveillance aircraft engaged in a United Nations mission.
articles.title: China jet fired flares at Canadian chopper in international waters: Ottawa

articles.description: Archaeologists in Morocco have discovered a Roman-era site in Rabat, which includes a port district, bath, and cemetery dating back to the second century. The site, now the third largest in Morocco, will provide insights into the lives of Roman settlers and romanised Moroccans during that time. The bath covers an area of over 2000 square meters and resembles imperial counterparts in Rome. The excavation is ongoing to uncover the port and other parts of one of the largest Roman towns in the country.
articles.title: Morocco unearths Roman-era second century site in Rabat

articles.description: A man's body was discovered inside a discarded suitcase during a routine cleanup around Oakland's Lake Merritt on Halloween. Volunteers found the body when they realized the suitcase was too heavy and unzipped it. The victim, believed to be in his 30s, was found in a fetal position. The investigation is ongoing, and authorities are trying to determine where the body could have come from. The incident has caused shock among local residents who consider the area a peaceful spot.
articles.title: Volunteers cleaning California lake on Halloween find 'murdered' man in suitcase

articles.description: A clothing company has been ordered to pay over $1 million to four American Airlines flight attendants who claimed that their uniforms caused health problems. The attendants attributed their rashes, headaches, and breathing issues to chemicals used in the production of the uniforms. The verdict may lead to further legal challenges, as more than 400 other flight attendants have made similar claims against the uniform manufacturer. American Airlines has since terminated its contract with the company and switched to a new uniform supplier.
articles.title: Flight attendants who blamed clothing company for health issues win California lawsuit

articles.description: A man in Florida has been arrested and charged with felony child abuse for allegedly attempting to circumcise a toddler he was babysitting. Timothoes Powell, 29, was taken into custody on Monday and is facing a first-degree aggravated child abuse charge. The incident came to light when a state Department of Children and Families investigator noticed the child's injuries. Powell initially claimed that he found a piece of glass in the child's diaper, but later admitted to causing the injury.
articles.title: Florida babysitter arrested for attempting to 'circumcise' toddler

articles.description: Secretary of State Antony Blinken will request brief cessations of military operations in Gaza from the Israeli government to allow for hostage releases and humanitarian aid distribution. This comes as President Biden revealed that Prime Minister Netanyahu had agreed to a temporary halt in shelling on October 20th for the release of two American hostages. The US is pushing for "humanitarian pauses" to address the urgent crisis for civilians in Gaza.
articles.title: United States to press Israel for 'pauses' in war against Hamas

articles.description: British prime minister Rishi Sunak on Thursday said that like-minded governments and artificial intelligence companies had reached agreement on testing new AI models before they were released. Sunak is hosting a 2-day AI Safety Summit where on Wednesday he secured China's backing for an international effort to manage the risks of the technology. On Thursday, Sunak announced a further "landmark agreement" with "like-minded governments and AI companies."
articles.title: Sunak unveils 'landmark' deal on safety testing of new AI models

articles.description: Israeli troops continued to fight with Hamas militants in Gaza City as the Palestinian death toll surpassed 9,000. US and Arab leaders urged Israel to ease its siege and temporarily halt attacks to aid civilians. US Secretary of State Antony Blinken planned to visit Israel and Jordan for talks. President Joe Biden suggested a humanitarian pause, but Israel did not immediately respond. Arab countries, including Jordan and Egypt, expressed unease with the war.
articles.title: Pressure on Israel to pause war as Gaza toll crosses 9 thousand

articles.description: Mohammadi has subsequently announced she would not under any circumstances wear a hijab, the head covering which has been obligatory for women in public spaces since shortly after Iran's 1979 Islamic revolution. Prison authorities in response have refused to transfer Mohammadi, who suffers from heart and lung conditions, to a hospital outside Evin, her family said in a statement, warning her health and life were at risk. The scan showed two veins with severe blockages and high lung pressure, with a coronary angiogram and lung scan urgently needed.
articles.title: Iran limiting jailed Nobel winner Narges Mohammadi's medical care over hijab refusal: Family

articles.description: The number of Americans applying for jobless benefits increased slightly last week but remains relatively low, despite the Federal Reserve's efforts to cool the economy and control inflation. Unemployment claims rose by 5,000 to 217,000 for the week ending October 28. The four-week moving average of claims also ticked up by 2,000 to 210,000. However, the American labor market continues to show resilience, with the economy adding jobs and consumer spending remaining strong.
articles.title: US applications for jobless benefits inch higher but remain at historically healthy levels

articles.description: Ukraine has stated that Russian attacks on the town of Avdiivka have decreased, but the Kremlin denies that the conflict is deadlocked. Avdiivka has been a focal point of fighting between Ukrainian and Russian forces since 2014. Ukrainian President Zelensky confirmed that his forces are mounting defensive actions in Avdiivka. While there are concerns that Russian forces may be regrouping for another wave of attacks, Ukraine claims to be largely in control. Both sides have struggled to make significant progress on the battlefield in recent months.
articles.title: Ukraine says Russian attacks easing around embattled town

articles.description: Two Lebanese shepherds were found dead near the border after being shot by Israeli forces. The Israeli army is looking into the report. The shepherds were tending to their flock near the Wazzani river. The incident occurred amid ongoing exchange of fire between Israeli forces and Hezbollah along the border. UNIFIL, the UN peacekeeping force, had been asked to assist in evacuating two injured individuals in the same area. The search for the injured was postponed until the next morning due to darkness and land mines.
articles.title: Bodies of Lebanese shepherds shot at by Israeli forces found-report

articles.description: US Vice President Kamala Harris and British Prime Minister Rishi Sunak are participating in a UK summit focused on addressing the risks associated with advanced artificial intelligence (AI). The summit, held at Bletchley Park, began with an agreement signed by 28 nations, including the US and China, to collaborate on understanding and managing AI risks. The summit aims to foster dialogue and cooperation rather than impose binding regulations.Sunak is expected to provide further details on his proposal for a global expert panel on AI.
articles.title: Harris and Sunak due to discuss cutting-edge AI risks at UK summit

articles.description: President Vladimir Putin has signed a bill to revoke Russia's ratification of the Comprehensive Nuclear Test Ban Treaty (CTBT), citing the need to establish parity with the United States. The CTBT, adopted in 1996, bans nuclear explosions globally but has not been fully implemented. Russia's move has raised concerns that it may resume nuclear tests to deter Western military support for Ukraine. However, Russian Deputy Foreign Minister Sergei Ryabkov stated that Moscow will only resume tests if the US does so first.
articles.title: Putin signs bill revoking Russia's ratification of global nuke test ban treaty

articles.description: Thousands of people are flooding Pakistan's northwestern border crossing into Afghanistan after the government's deadline for undocumented foreigners to leave expired. Pakistani authorities have been rounding up undocumented foreigners, primarily Afghans, citing their involvement in militant attacks and crime. Over a million Afghans may have to leave Pakistan or face arrest and forcible expulsion. More than 24,000 Afghans crossed into Afghanistan on Wednesday alone, with thousands more expected to follow.
articles.title: Pakistan-Afghanistan border crossing overwhelmed as Afghans face expulsion

articles.description: Egypt has announced that it will help evacuate around 7,000 foreigners and dual nationals from the war-torn Gaza Strip. The Rafah border crossing opened on Wednesday for the first time in weeks, allowing people to leave Gaza. Around 400 people were expected to cross on Thursday, including 60 wounded individuals. The exact timeline and details of the evacuation were not provided. The Egyptian official clarified that 361 foreigners and dual nationals had entered Egypt on Wednesday. The number of wounded included 46 patients and 30 accompanying individuals.
articles.title: Egypt says to help evacuate 'about 7,000' Gaza foreign nationals

articles.description: An earthquake of magnitude 5.7 struck the central Philippines on Tuesday, the USGS said. The offshore quake was at a depth of 19.2 km (12 miles), USGS said, off the central province of Eastern Samar. The Philippine Institute of Volcanology and Seismology warned of damage and aftershocks in an advisory but there were no immediate reports of casualties. The Philippines lies on the "Ring of Fire", a belt of volcanoes circling the Pacific Ocean that is prone to earthquakes.
articles.title: Magnitude 5.7 earthquake strikes central Philippines: USGS

articles.author: Asmita Dey
articles.description: India Business News: NEW DELHI: As it looks to widen its focus on the Gen Z segment, stock broking platform Angel One has acquired the team of Bengaluru-based fintech star.
articles.title: Angel One acquires fintech startup Dstreet

articles.description: An investigation is underway in China regarding a fraudulent "tumor research institute" where a woman's mother was deceived into paying $27,000 for fake cancer treatments. The woman and her mother were introduced to a traditional Chinese medicine practitioner who claimed to have a cure for cancer. The practitioner administered questionable treatments, including bloodletting and applying cement to the skin. It was later revealed that the practitioner had no medical qualifications and the certificates he provided were fake.
articles.title: China’s ‘tumor research institute’ scam: Woman duped during bizarre cancer treatment

articles.description: South Korea's military has assessed that North Korea has likely supplied various types of missiles to Russia to support its war in Ukraine. This comes after reports that North Korea provided over a million artillery shells to Russia. The military believes that North Korea has also sent short-range ballistic missiles, anti-tank missiles, and portable anti-air missiles to Russia, among other weapons. South Korea, the US, and Japan have condemned these weapons shipments, which violate UN Security Council resolutions.
articles.title: North Korea has likely sent missiles, ammunition, shells to Russia, Seoul says

articles.description: Rest of World News: MANILA: The Philippine foreign ministry on Thursday accused China of intruding into its waters after an incident at a disputed shoal in the South Chin.
articles.title: Philippines accuses China of intruding into its waters

articles.description: Four crew members died Wednesday when an air ambulance crashed in the central Mexican state of Morelos. The incident took place just before 14:30 p.m. local time, in a wooded, mountainous area near the town of Tetlama, Temixco: a township roughly 30 miles (50 kilometers) south of Mexico City. Officials from the army, National Guard and state security departments responded to the crash, the state department for civil protection reported on X, the social network formerly known as Twitter.
articles.title: Air ambulance crash kills 4 crew members in central Mexico

articles.description: Islamic extremist rebels in northeastern Nigeria killed at least 37 villagers in two separate attacks, marking a resurgence of violence in the region. The first attack occurred in Yobe state's Geidam district, where gunmen shot and killed 17 villagers. The following day, a land mine exploded, killing 20 people attending the burial of the victims from the previous attack. The Boko Haram group has been responsible for the insurgency in Nigeria since 2009, resulting in over 35,000 deaths and the displacement of millions of people.
articles.title: Extremists kill 37 villagers in latest attack in Nigeria's hard-hit northeast

articles.description: China and the United States are set to hold their first nuclear arms control talks since the Obama administration. The discussions, scheduled for next week, will focus on arms control and non-proliferation, as well as maritime affairs and other issues. The talks come after US officials expressed frustration over China's lack of interest in reducing nuclear weapons risks. China currently has over 500 operational nuclear warheads, a number that is expected to rise to over 1,000 by 2030.
articles.title: China agrees to nuclear arms-control talks with US: Report

articles.description: Six terrorists were killed during an operation in the Sambaza area of Balochistan's Zhob district. Security forces conducted the operation based on intelligence reports. The Inter-Services Public Relations (ISPR) stated that the terrorists were involved in activities against security forces and targeting innocent civilians. A cache of arms, ammunition, and explosives was also recovered. The area is being sanitized to eliminate other militants. Pakistan has witnessed an increase in terrorism, particularly in Khyber Pakhtunkhwa and Balochistan.
articles.title: Pakistan: Six terrorists killed in Balochistan's Zhob

articles.description: President Joe Biden will visit the community of Lewiston, Maine, to mourn the victims of the deadliest mass shooting in the state's history. The shooting took place on October 25, resulting in 18 deaths and 13 injuries. Biden and First Lady Jill Biden will pay their respects to the victims, meet with first responders, and grieve with the community. The alleged gunman, Robert Card, was found dead of an apparent suicide after a manhunt. Investigators are focusing on Card's mental health as a possible motive.
articles.title: Biden and the first lady will travel to Maine to mourn with the community after the mass shooting

articles.description: Donald Trump Jr testified in a civil fraud trial that he never worked on his father's financial statements, which are at the center of the trial. The lawsuit alleges that the former president and his business misled banks and insurers by inflating his net worth on the statements. Trump Jr said he signed off on the statements as a trustee but left the work to outside accountants. Eric Trump is also expected to testify in the trial, followed by the former president himself. The trial is in its second month and is being closely watched.
articles.title: Donald Trump Jr testifies he never worked on the key documents in his father's civil fraud trial

articles.description: A US couple has been fined $28,000 by a court in Uganda after pleading guilty to child cruelty and "inhumane treatment" of their 10-year-old foster child. The couple admitted to making the child sleep on a wooden platform and feeding him cold food. They were sentenced to two months in prison, which they have already served, and ordered to pay the victim $26,000 in compensation. The case has sparked criticism from child rights activists in Uganda, who have called it a travesty of justice.
articles.title: Uganda court fines US couple $28,000 for 'inhumane treatment' of their foster child

articles.description: Hostels in China have become refuges for young people struggling to find jobs in major cities. As joblessness among young Chinese reaches record highs, hostels provide a place for individuals to stay between interviews and strategize for their next networking meeting. The hypercompetitive nature of China's white-collar job market, combined with a slowing economy, has made it increasingly difficult for young people to secure well-paying jobs. Even those who have found employment often struggle to afford housing. The situation has worsened in recent years, with fewer job offers available.
articles.title: For China's jobless young people, hostels are the place to be

articles.description: A Sikh man was killed by an American, after a minor car crash in October, was motivated by "rage inflamed by hate," the Queens district attorney said. The accused Gilbert Augustin following the crash repeatedly beat the victim, Jasmer Singh and called him "turban man." The new charges filed against him Tuesday included manslaughter and assault as hate crimes. Augustin faces up to 25 years in prison if convicted.
articles.title: US man who beat Sikh man to death faces hate charge

articles.description: At least 43 military aircraft and seven ships China sent to Taiwan, a  latest sign that Beijing plans no let-up in its campaign of harassment, threats and intimidation. Taiwan's defence ministry said 37 of the aircraft had crossed the median line in the Taiwan Strait, which China no longer recognises as an informal divider between the sides.
articles.title: China sends 43 aircraft, 7 ships close to Taiwan

articles.author: Ch Sushil Rao
articles.description: A 29-year-old student from Telangana, India, named Putcha Varun Raj, was stabbed in the head by a man at a gym in Indiana, United States. The attacker, Jordan Andrade, claimed that he found Varun "a little weird" and felt threatened by him. Varun, who was pursuing his MS in computer science, had a slim chance of survival due to the severity of his injuries. Varun's family has requested assistance from the government, and the Indian embassy and NRIs from Telangana have pledged their support.
articles.title: 29-year-old Indian student stabbed at gym in US, critical

articles.description: Actor Matthew Perry was found unresponsive and not breathing in his hot tub at his California residence. The Los Angeles Fire Department arrived at the scene but Perry was already deceased. An autopsy has been completed, but the cause of death has been deferred pending further tests. Foul play is not suspected at this time. Perry was best known for his role as Chandler Bing on the sitcom "Friends," and his co-stars have expressed their grief over his loss.
articles.title: New details emerge after Matthew Perry's autopsy, cause of death 'deferred'

articles.description: American commandos are assisting Israel in locating and rescuing the hostages taken during Hamas' cross-border attacks. The US Special Operations forces are working alongside FBI and state department experts to coordinate efforts with Israeli counterparts. While the commandos are not assigned combat roles, they are advising on the complexities of a potential ground invasion of Gaza. The US forces in the region are also prepared to assist American citizens and secure embassies if needed. The exact number of commandos deployed has not been disclosed.
articles.title: US commandos on the ground in Israel helping to locate hostages

articles.description: Jordan, a key US ally, said Wednesday it has recalled its ambassador from Israel and told Israel's ambassador to remain out of the country in protest over the "humanitarian catastrophe" in Gaza. Jordan's deputy PM said the return of the ambassadors is linked to Israel "stopping its war on Gaza ... and the humanitarian catastrophe it is causing." Jordan signed a peace deal with Israel in 1994. Meanwhile, Bolivia said on Tuesday it had broken diplomatic ties with Israel
articles.title: Jordan, a key ally of US, recalls its envoy from Israel

articles.description: Countries such as India, UK, US, and China have agreed to collaborate in order to protect against the potential harm caused by artificial intelligence (AI). This agreement was reached at the world's first summit on AI safety, held in Bletchley Park, UK. The participating nations signed the "Bletchley Declaration," emphasizing the need to collectively manage the risks associated with AI. While the declaration lacks specific policy goals, a second meeting is scheduled in South Korea and a third in France.
articles.title: 28 countries and EU sign pact against AI's 'catastrophic' risks

articles.description: An Indian-origin Israeli soldier was killed while fighting against Hamas in Gaza. Staff-Sgt. Halel Solomon, 20, was from the southern Israeli town of Dimona. Dimona’s mayor, Benny Bitton took his Facebook and said, ​​“It is with great sorrow and grief that we announce the death of a son of Dimona, Halel Solomon, in the battle in Gaza."
articles.title: PIO soldier among 16 Israelis killed in a battle inside Gaza

articles.description: The Israeli military said it had deployed missile boats in the Red Sea on Wednesday as reinforcements, a day after the Iran-aligned Houthi movement said it had launched missile and drone attacks on Israel and vowed to carry out more. Images disseminated by the military showed Saar-class corvettes patrolling near Eilat port in the Red Sea, which Israel sees as a new front as its war in Gaza draws retaliation from Iran-aligned pro-Hamas forces elsewhere in the region
articles.title: Israel puts missile boats in Red Sea as Houthis attack from Yemen

articles.description: At least 320 foreign passport holders and injured Gazans were evacuated from the Palestinian enclave through the Rafah crossing into Egypt on Wednesday, under a deal mediated by Qatar. Initially, 500 foreign passport holders were expected to be allowed out of Gaza in the coming days. Talks are ongoing for further evacuations, with the US aiming to evacuate 400 Americans. The limited evacuations come after more than three weeks of a total blockade of Gaza by Israel, following an attack by Hamas fighters. Hospitals in Gaza are also facing a critical shortage of fuel.
articles.title: First evacuees exit Gaza as refugee camp struck again

articles.description: Patrick Dai, who has been accused of making violent threats against Jewish students, was arrested. He called for the deaths of Jewish people and said he was ‘gonna shoot up 104 west.'
articles.title: Cornell student held for threats to Jews

articles.description: The US Federal Reserve has decided to maintain interest rates at a 22-year high for the second consecutive meeting in an effort to control inflation without harming the strong economy. The Fed aims to cool down demand and encourage companies to slow down price increases. Despite the economy's resilience, inflation has gradually decreased from its peak in 2022. The Fed is focused on bringing inflation back in line with its 2% target and is considering whether to implement one final rate increase in the coming months.
articles.title: US Federal Reserve keeps interest rates at 22-year high

articles.description: Italian Prime Minister Giorgia Meloni expressed international fatigue with the conflict in Ukraine and a lack of support for Italy in dealing with migration in a phone call with Russian pranksters. The 13-minute audio of the call, released by the pranksters, revealed Meloni's frustration with the situation. She also criticized the belief that Italy should solve the migration problem alone. The pranksters praised Meloni for sharing her genuine opinions, unlike other European politicians who act like programmed robots.
articles.title: Italy PM Giorgia Meloni talks of Ukraine fatigue, migration in prank call

articles.author: Andrew Jeong, Kelsey Ables, Victoria Bisset, Loveday Morris, Bryan Pietsch, Carrie Keller-Lynn, Andrea Salcedo
articles.description: Defense Secretary Lloyd Austin restricted Pentagon transportation for official travel to Israel; a senior defense official said, “it’s just not a safe time to travel there.”
articles.title: Israel-Gaza live updates: No ‘temporary cease-fire’ without return of hostages, Netanyahu says

articles.author: Maegan Vazquez
articles.description: Rep. Rashida Tlaib (D-Mich.), the only Palestinian American in the House, posted a video to social media Friday seemingly to pressure Biden to support a cease-fire in the conflict.
articles.title: Democratic House member accuses Biden of supporting Palestinian ‘genocide’

articles.author: Michael Birnbaum, Karen DeYoung
articles.description: Hamas has claimed it would release all of its civilian hostages in exchange for a five-day pause in Israel’s offensive, diplomats say.
articles.title: Israel appears to reject U.S. push for ‘pauses’ in Gaza assault

articles.author: Loveday Morris, Sarah Dadouch, Meg Kelly, Evan Hill
articles.description: The strike was the latest in a series of attacks on health infrastructure in Gaza, where Israeli forces are engaged in a large-scale offensive to destroy Hamas.
articles.title: Israel launches deadly strike on ambulance outside hospital in Gaza

articles.author: Bryan Pietsch
articles.description: Hasan Nasrallah, the head of Hezbollah, gave his first address Friday since the Oct. 7 Hamas attack on Israel.
articles.title: Who is Hasan Nasrallah, the leader of Hezbollah?

articles.author: Kareem Fahim, Sarah Dadouch, William Booth, Ellen Francis
articles.description: Hassan Nasrallah’s speech was closely watched around the Middle East for signs of whether Hezbollah would escalate its attacks on northern Israel.
articles.title: Hezbollah leader signals no major shift in clashes with Israel

articles.author: Karla Adam
articles.description: President Emmanuel Macron submitted language for an amendment that would make France the first country to enshrine a right to abortion in its constitution.
articles.title: Macron moves to add abortion to France’s constitution, reacting to U.S.

articles.author: Joanna Slater, Emily Wax-Thibodeaux, Dan Rosenzweig-Ziff
articles.description: A scholar. A former nurse. A Missouri native who died shielding her teenage son. They’re among the Americans killed in Saturday’s terrorist attacks in Israel.
articles.title: At least 32 Americans were killed in Israel. Here’s what we know so far.

articles.author: Daniel Wolfe
articles.description: Clean water was already hard to come by in Gaza before the war. As fuel runs out, it is becoming nearly impossible to find. Here’s why.
articles.title: Water is running out in Gaza. It will mean more deaths.

articles.author: William Booth,  Ilan Ben Zion
articles.description: Israeli troops could face an urban battlefield in Gaza with militants staging attacks and escapes through a vast network of underground tunnels.
articles.title: How Gaza’s tunnel network leaves Israel facing ‘three-dimensional’ war

articles.author: Michael E. Miller
articles.description: As Australia and the U.S. look to address China’s near dominance of the vital critical minerals market, Anthony Albanese is the first Australian leader to visit Beijing in seven years.
articles.title: As Australian leader heads to China, a critical (minerals) issue looms

articles.author: Christian Shepherd, Lyric Li
articles.description: Beijing has wasted no time weighing in on the conflict, trying to bolster its status as a champion of developing countries and as a rival to the United States.
articles.title: Where China stands on the Israel-Gaza war and what it stands to gain

articles.author: Justine McDaniel, Mohamad  El Chamaa, Frances Vinall
articles.description: Hezbollah and Israel, longtime enemies, have traded shelling since Hamas’s attack on Israel.
articles.title: What is Hezbollah, the militant group on Israel’s northern border?

articles.author: Kyle Melnick
articles.description: Bunbury’s mayor denied that playing “Hot Potato” was meant to deter homeless people, but the Wiggles weren’t happy the Australian city used their song.
articles.title: The Wiggles object after ‘Hot Potato’ blasted nonstop near homeless camp

articles.author: Shibani Mahtani, Timothy McLaughlin
articles.description: Violence in one Hong Kong neighborhood on July 21, 2019, would rupture whatever hope existed for compromise between the authorities and pro-democracy protesters.
articles.title: As Hong Kong stood up for democracy, a neighborhood was brutalized

articles.author: Ishaan Tharoor
articles.description: The Biden administration championed Israel’s right to defend itself as it saw fit. Unlike leaders and diplomats in other parts of the world, U.S. officials were more subdued in their expressions of concern for the civilians killed amid relentless Israeli aerial bombardments.
articles.title: In embrace of Israel’s war, Biden provokes Arab and Muslim backlash

articles.author: Frances Vinall, Niha Masih, Andrew Jeong, Annabelle Timsit, Jennifer Hassan, Adam Taylor, Sammy Westfall, Michael Birnbaum, Maham Javaid, Amber Ferguson
articles.description: Secretary of State Antony Blinken is expected to push Israel to engage in “humanitarian pauses” in its invasion of Gaza during a trip to the Middle East, a senior administration official said.
articles.title: Israel-Gaza war live updates: Blinken to push for ‘humanitarian pauses’; leading Democrat calls for changes in Israeli strategy

articles.author: Bryan Pietsch
articles.description: Here’s what to know about the U.S. citizens and other foreign nationals stuck in the Gaza Strip.
articles.title: What to know about the Americans and other foreign nationals in Gaza

articles.author: Loveday Morris
articles.description: “We are at the height of war,” Israel’s Chief of Staff, Gen. Herzi Halevi, said Thursday as troops “surrounded” Gaza City, bringing new perils for civilians.
articles.title: Israeli forces push deeper into Gaza as invasion expands, risks multiply

articles.author: Sarah Dadouch
articles.description: An expected speech by Hezbollah’s leader Hassan Nasrallah could give clues over whether the militant groups will expands attack on northern Israel.
articles.title: Lebanon, fearing wider war, awaits signals from Hezbollah’s leader

articles.author: Michael Rosenwald
articles.description: As founder of the Dangerous Sports Club at Oxford, David Kirke orchestrated stunts including the first bungee jump and skiing down Swiss slopes on a grand piano.
articles.title: David Kirke, first bungee jumper and extreme sports patriarch, dies at 78

articles.author: Loay Ayyoub, Miriam Berger, Hajar Harb
articles.description: A child is killed every 10 minutes in Gaza, Save the Children says. Families are mourning not just their own losses, but what feels like the loss of an entire generation.
articles.title: Gaza becomes ‘a graveyard for children’ as Israel intensifies airstrikes

articles.author: Hajar Harb, Kareem Fahim, Bryan Pietsch, Joanna Slater
articles.description: Some Americans said they were still encountering difficulties at the border, because the names of relatives were not on the list of those approved to exit.
articles.title: Dozens of U.S. citizens depart Gaza as Israel presses offensive

articles.author: Anthony Faiola, Cat Zakrzewski
articles.description: As countries concluded a landmark summit on Artificial Intelligence at Bletchley Park, the historic site of WWII code breakers, they faced a vexing modern-day reality.
articles.title: Governments used to lead innovation. On AI, they’re falling behind.

articles.author: Dan Stillman, Ellen Francis, Matthew Cappucci
articles.description: The storm cut power to 1.2 million people in France and has been blamed for at least 5 deaths.
articles.title: Deadly Storm Ciarán blasts western Europe, sets wind records in France

articles.author: Tim Page
articles.description: He rebuilt the St. Petersburg Philharmonic after the collapse of communism and later led the Baltimore Symphony Orchestra.
articles.title: Yuri Temirkanov, world-renowned conductor, dies at 84

articles.author: Washington Post Staff, Dan Stillman
articles.description: A storm that raged through northwestern France overnight was hitting Britain on Thursday with heavy rainfall and winds that prompted the country’s weather agency to issue its second-highest alert level for parts of southern England.
articles.title: In photos: Storm Ciarán lashes the U.K. after battering northwestern France

articles.author: Claire Parker, Victoria Bisset, Ellen Francis
articles.description: The link between Egypt and Gaza is the only route for aid convoys to enter and foreign citizens to leave the besieged Palestinian enclave.
articles.title: Why Egypt’s Rafah border crossing is vital for Gaza’s humanitarian crisis

articles.author: Jennifer Hassan, Niha Masih
articles.description: At least 33 journalists have been killed in the Israel-Gaza war since Oct. 7; the majority of those killed so far, 28, were Palestinians in the Gaza Strip.
articles.title: Journalists killed in the Israel-Gaza war: A look at the lives lost

articles.author: Drew Harwell, Taylor Lorenz
articles.description: The Israel-Gaza war has again placed TikTok at the center of a heated global argument over the app’s risks and power.
articles.title: Israel-Gaza war sparks debate over TikTok’s role in setting public opinion

articles.author: Emily Rauhala
articles.description: Far-right voices have played up the possibility of mass migration from the Middle East, though few Palestinians have been able to leave.
articles.title: As crisis unfolds in Gaza, Europe talks about tightening borders

articles.author: Rachel Pannett
articles.description: Three of four guests at Erin Patterson’s lunch in Leongatha died within a week of the meal. Authorities suspect they ate death cap mushrooms.
articles.title: Australian woman charged in suspected mushroom poisoning deaths

articles.author: Chico Harlan
articles.description: In South Sudan, war and semi-permanent flooding have left people to scavenge for food, with long-term consequences for their health.
articles.title: Years into a climate disaster, these people are eating the unthinkable

articles.author: Anastacia Galouchka
articles.description: Two Ukrainian brothers were inseparable. So when Russia invaded, they went to fight together. One family’s toll of war mirrors the grief of an entire nation.
articles.title: In peace and war, these Ukrainian brothers bonded. Then death came.

articles.description: Israeli officials and commentators are floating vague ideas of an endgame as Israel continues its punishing campaign in the Gaza Strip.
articles.title: Israel makes a desolation and may call it peace

articles.title: Tracking damage within the Gaza Strip through maps

articles.description: China said it wanted to work with international partners to manage the oversight of artificial intelligence as political leaders and technology executives gathered at an inaugural AI Safety Summit in Britain to plot the way forward.

articles.description: A 43-year-old man in the United States has been arrested for allegedly pointing a gun at a 6-year-old boy over Halloween candy.

articles.description:
Oct. 27 – Nov. 2, 2023

Revelers celebrate Halloween at the West Side Hallo Fest in Romania, storm Ciaran whips Western Europe, blowing record winds in France and UK, and South Africa beats New Zealand to win Rugby World Cup title in Paris.

This gallery highlights some of the most compelling images made or published in the past week by Associated Press photographers in Europe and Africa.

The selection was curated by AP photographer Thibault Camus in France.

___

Follow AP visual journalism:

Instagram: https://www.instagram.com/apnews

AP Images on Twitter: http://twitter.com/AP_Images

AP Images blog: http://apimagesblog.com
articles.title: AP Week in Pictures: Europe and Africa

articles.description:
Oct. 27-Nov. 2, 2023

A student activist resists detention while gathering to protest against Israel’s military operations in Gaza and to support the Palestinian people, in New Delhi. Activists of the Bangladesh Nationalist Party face police during a protest in Dhaka. A devotee lights oil lamps during celebrations of the full moon day of Thadingyut, or lighting festival, to mark the end of Buddhist Lent in Naypyitaw, Myanmar.

This photo gallery highlights some of the most compelling images in Asia made or published by The Associated Press in the past week.

The selection was curated by AP photo editor Masayo Yoshida in Tokyo.

Follow AP visual journalism:

Instagram: https://www.instagram.com/apnews

AP Images on Twitter: http://twitter.com/AP_Images

AP Images blog: http://apimagesblog.com
articles.title: AP Week in Pictures: Asia

Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu has rejected any ceasefire that does not include the release of hostages. Charlie D'Agata has more.

articles.description: Since the attack against Israel by Hamas militants on Oct. 7, violence against Palestinians living in the Israeli-occupied West Bank has escalated, with at least 121 people killed.

Since then, the American-born mother and her children have arrived in Santa Monica, California. She joins "CBS Mornings" to describe her family's journey.

articles.description: The Israeli military says it is encircling Gaza City on three sides. But as it battles Hamas militants above ground, danger lurks below from an advanced network of underground tunnels known as the "Gaza Metro," which Hamas uses to house command and control centers, and store weapons. Charlie D'Agata has more.

articles.description:
Buildings destroyed after the earthquake on February 13, 2023, in Hatay, Turkey. | Murat Saka/dia images via Getty Images
    

  
Turkey is investigating and has arrested some contractors, but the entire political and economic system is implicated.
 Turkey is still in the middle of an emergency, reeling from the earthquake that killed at least 35,000 people last week. But the finger-pointing has already begun. 
The rush to punishment comes amid the grief, but also the mounting fury and frustration over the Turkish government’s earthquake response. Much of that is focused on the emergency response — waiting for aid and rescue teams — but it is also extending to anger about policies before the earthquake, about how shoddy building construction may have exacerbated the devastation of the dis…
articles.title: Who is responsible for Turkey’s bad buildings?

articles.description:
Getty Images
    

  
How we turned 20,000 Soviet nukes into zero-carbon energy — and how we can do the same with some of our own.
 Just a decade ago, one in 10 American lightbulbs was powered by dismantled Russian nuclear weapons.
That was made possible by the Megatons to Megawatts program, an agreement negotiated after the collapse of the Soviet Union to convert uranium from Russia’s nuclear weapons stockpile into fuel for US nuclear power plants. The unconventional policy was first proposed by MIT physicist Thomas Neff in a 1991 New York Times op-ed. By the time Megatons to Megawatts ran its full course from 1993 to 2013, it had eliminated about 20,000 nuclear warheads and stood out as a point of shared pride in the often jaded arms control and disarmament field. “Nearly every commercia…
articles.title: 10 years ago, we were turning nuclear bombs into nuclear energy. We can do it again.

articles.description:
Volunteers stand on rubble of a destroyed building in Kahramanmaras, Turkey, on February 7, 2023. | Adem Altan/AFP via Getty Images
    

  
What Turkey and Syria’s deadly earthquakes reveal about wealth.
 In the early hours of Monday, February 6, residents living in southern Turkey and northern Syria were woken by violent shaking, collapsing buildings, and sweeping blackouts. The earthquake buried residents in rubble and was followed by powerful aftershocks. By the following Monday, the death toll had passed 36,000 people. “It was like the apocalypse,” Abdul Salam al-Mahmoud, a resident of Atareb, Syria, told Reuters.  
The country is no stranger to quakes, having lost 17,000 people to a 7.4-magnitude tremor in 1999. But while last week’s earthquake was a 7.8-magnitude quake, and had an u…
articles.title: Why earthquakes are deadlier depending on where you live

articles.description:
A suspected Chinese spy balloon flies above Charlotte, North Carolina, on February 4, 2023.  | Peter Zay/Anadolu Agency via Getty Images
    

  
As all these objects fall, a new space race is rising.
 Now that the US military has shot down a suspected spy balloon from China and three other unidentified flying objects, there will be debates about the UFOs’ meaning, their capabilities, and why they were all up there in the first place. 
Though former CIA Director Michael Hayden said the initial balloon’s threat to the welfare of Americans was vastly inflated, others described the incident as a wake-up call. Former Trump national security adviser H.R. McMaster hopes it will lead to a “Sputnik moment,” harkening back to the US space race with the Soviet Union. The Wall Street Journal even war…
articles.title: Why the balloon and UFO affairs are a Sputnik moment

articles.author: Lara BULLENS
articles.description: For Gaza's two million residents, the Rafah border with Egypt serves as a vital lifeline. Over the years, this crossing has seen numerous shifts, openings, and closures, prompting the construction of illicit tunnels beneath it to facilitate the flow of people and goods. As the war between Israel and Hamas persists, the Rafah border now plays a crucial role in evacuations and the delivery of humanitarian aid.
articles.title: The Gaza-Egypt Rafah crossing explained: ‘It is not a normal border’

articles.author: FRANCE24
articles.description: Thailand is the nation with the most foreign workers affected by the crisis in Israel, as 32 Thais have been confirmed dead, 19 injured, and 23 hostages are being held by Hamas. The Thai government is pleading for their release and has implemented a policy of paying for repatriation flights for migrant workers. FRANCE 24’s reporters were at Suvnarbhumi Airport in Bangkok this morning to welcome a plane carrying Thais home from Israel.
articles.title: Thai nationals welcomed home after evacuation from Israel

articles.author: William HILDERBRANDT
articles.description: In this special edition of Access Asia, we're at Paris's Quai Branly museum, where a new exhibition, "Bollywood superstars", looks back at a century of the Indian film industry. With more than 2,000 movies per year, Bollywood is the biggest movie industry in the world. It evolved from performing arts and silent films to today's big blockbusters. We speak to the exhibition's co-curator Julien Rousseau, as well as Mahina Khanum, a Bollywood dancer and choreographer. Plus, we explore how India's ruling Bharatiya Janata Party (BJP) is increasingly using the country's cinema to push its Hindu nationalist agenda.
articles.title: Bollywood superstars: Paris exhibition delves into a century of Indian cinema

articles.author: NEWS WIRES
articles.description: Levi's and H&M are among top global clothing brands to suffer production halts in Bangladesh, a garment union leader said Friday, after days of violent protests by workers demanding a near-tripling of their wages.
articles.title: Bangladesh garment worker protests halt production for top fashion brands

articles.author: Chris HUBY
articles.description: The city of Raqqa symbolises the tragic fate of Syria over the past 12 years. From the start of the uprising against President Bashar al-Assad in 2011, the northern city was a major target for rebel groups. It then became the stronghold of Islamic State group terrorists, who made Raqqa the capital of their self-proclaimed caliphate. The city went through three years of hell – suffering atrocities, public hangings and slave auctions – before being bombed and then liberated in 2017 by an international US-led coalition. Since then, the "Pearl of the Euphrates" has struggled to get back on track.
articles.title: Syria's Raqqa struggles to rebuild after years of rule by Islamic State group

articles.description: A mob in a small town in Senegal dug up the body of a man suspected of being gay, dragged his body through the streets and then burned it during the night of October 28, 2023. While there have been other instances of exhumations of people suspected of being gay, the incident that took place in Kaolack, a town 200 kilometres southeast of Dakar, is different because it was filmed and posted online, says our Observer, a member of a group dedicated to upholding the human rights of LGBT Africans.
articles.title: 'In Senegal, homophobia follows you even after death': Mob exhumes, burns corpse

articles.author: Christophe BARREYRE
articles.description: Ten years ago, French radio journalists Ghislaine Dupont and Claude Verlon were murdered by a commando from al Qaeda in the Islamic Maghreb in the north-eastern Malian town of Kidal. Since then, the security situation in Africa’s Sahel region has continually worsened. Today, the vast area stretching from Mauritania to Sudan has become a no man's land for journalists, a black hole for news.
articles.title: Africa's Sahel region: A media desert

articles.author: FRANCE24
articles.description: After more than 600 days since the Russian invasion, psychics and fortune tellers offering predictions on when the war will end are becoming increasingly popular in Ukraine with some soothsayers’ military forecasts racking up hundreds of thousands of views on social media. The phenomenon, according to one psychologist, comes down to people finding ways to cope with the “unbearable uncertainty” clouding the country’s future.
articles.title: ‘Unbearable uncertainty’: Ukrainians turn to psychics to know when war will end

articles.description: Russian journalist Elena Kostyuchenko has survived a poisoning attempt and managed to evade a Chechen hit squad, but the attempts on her life have not dissuaded her from becoming one of Russia's most outspoken dissenters. She has just published her first book, "I Love Russia", which she wrote while in exile abroad.

articles.description: The International Day to End Impunity for Crimes Against Journalists is marked on Thursday, November 2. The date was chosen as it also marks the death anniversary of RFI journalists Ghislaine Dupont and Claude Verlon, who were assassinated in Mali. Their families are still demanding the truth about what happened to them, but face a number of obstacles – in particular, the suspension of legal cooperation between Paris and Bamako due to their diplomatic row.

articles.description: Some pro-Israeli social media users are claiming that Palestinians are posting videos pretending to be injured by the bombing campaign carried out by Israel since October 7. On October 26, for example, pro-Israeli accounts started sharing claims that a Palestinian video maker had pretended to be injured. Their so-called proof was two videos – one said to show the man in a hospital bed and the next one, apparently filmed the next day, showing him in perfect health. It turns out, however, that the video of the injured man is from August 2023, months before the war broke out. Moreover, it shows another man – and a real victim of the ongoing conflict.
articles.title: No, this video doesn’t show a Palestinian pretending to be injured in the Israel-Hamas war

Some 200,000 Afghans have already left Pakistan voluntarily – albeit often reluctantly – ahead of the November 1 deadline. Our correspondents Shahzaib Wahlah and Sonia Ghezali report.

articles.author: M.L. Nestel
articles.description:
She tried to censure and it came up short. 
Now she's shaming the names who didn't vote in favor. 
Rep. Marjorie Taylor Greene (R-GA) had willed a resolution to censure Rep. Rashida Tlaib (D-MI) for her attendance of a protest opposing the war in Gaza. 
POLL: Should Trump be allowed to run for office?
"List of feckless Republicans that voted WITH Democrats to table my censure resolution against Rashida Tlaib," Greene said on Wednesday. "This is why Republicans NEVER do anything to stop the communists Democrats or ever hold anyone accountable!! PATHETIC."

She created a social media thread naming some of her friends in the House who didn't have what it took to vote with her. 
They include current House Speaker Mike Johnson, Rep. Chip Roy (R-TX), and Rep. Ken Buck (R-CO) who announced he wasn't running for reelection. 

	Earlier in the week, Greene preemptively lashed out after learning that her effort wasn't gaining a coalition in Congress.
"I want to remind you, this happened on the same day Hezbollah declared a day of immense anger," she said. "And Rashida Tlaib organized with that group. And they did. They did protest, and they did an insurrection into our Capitol complex, stopping Congress and stopping the Senate."
The media was quick to take notice of the lawmaker's swing and miss Wednesday.
"Colleague Kelly Phares rpts 23 GOPers join Dems to table or kill effort to censure Dem MI Rep Tlaib," tweeted Chat Pergram.
Melanie Zanona also tweeted: "motion to table — aka kill — MTG’s resolution to censure Rep. Rashida Tlaib just passed the House, with help of 23 Republicans."

And CNN's Manu Raju added that the effort to take on Tlaib quickly died tweeting: "House kills resolution to censure Rashida Tlaib. 23 Republicans voted with Dems. MTG offered the resolution."
articles.title: 'Pathetic': Marjorie Taylor Greene attacks 'feckless Republicans' who voted against her

articles.author: Sarah K. Burris
articles.description:
Sen. Tommy Tuberville's (R-AL) blockade appears to be coming to an end, according to an MSNBC report. 
Capitol reporter Ali Vitali said that a group of Republicans were going to take to the Senate floor and force a vote with Democrats to marginalize Tuberville's protest against military promotions that has led to a reduced military readiness for the United States, according to reports.
After a discussion about the absurdity of the protest, host Nicolle Wallace said that she recalled the era when Republicans had to be supportive of the military or they'd be shamed by leaders like Sen. Mitch McConnell (R-KY) and the GOP speaker. 
POLL: Should Trump be allowed to run for office?
Taking to social media, reporter Andrew Desiderio confirmed the reporting, saying that the floor actions will take place tonight, where they will ask for unanimous consent on ending the Tuberville blockade. He said that he was told it would be led by Sen. Dan Sullivan (R-AK). 
The news comes after reports that McConnell threatened Sen. Josh Hawley (R-MO) over his bill to stop corporations from being able to give money to campaigns. McConnell reportedly pointed to Hawley in the caucus lunch and said he wouldn't be there if it wasn't for the money from his Senate Leadership PAC. He went on to threaten any member who supported the bill with a primary. 
It's the first such action heard about from McConnell since he suffered serious injuries from a series of falls and then appeared to freeze at various public press availabilities.
articles.title: Republicans to join Dems in breaking Tuberville's blockade on military promotions: report

articles.author: M.L. Nestel
articles.description:
He drew a hard line in the sand, stalling hundreds of promotions of military brass. 
That line is budging. 
Officials are fuming at  Sen. Tommy Tuberville (R-AL) after it was discovered over the weekend that Marine Corps Commandant Gen. Eric Smith, who had been doubling as both the top No. 1 and No. 2 Marine Corps leader since July, suffered an apparent heart attack and was hospitalized on Sunday — leaving a three-star general to hold the prestigious post, according to a report published by Politico.
POLL: Should Trump be allowed to run for office?
The potential overextension of Smith and the stalling of more than 300 critical leadership roles was iced out by Tuberville's blockade installed as a protest against the Pentagon's policy to permit time off and reimbursement for abortions.  
Now…
articles.title: Tuberville's military blockade has 'added danger' after top Marine's heart attack: report
